Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Student Participation at the 2019 ASME-IMECE Micro and Nano Technology Forum; Salt Lake City, Utah; November 10-14, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to provide partial travel support for post-docs and graduate and undergraduate students to attend the American Society of Mechanical Engineers International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition in Salt Lake City, Utah, November 10-14, 2019. The students will participate in the ASME Society-Wide Micro and Nano Technology Forum (Topic 17-15), which focuses on new research in the field of micro and nano engineering and science. The students will present through oral and poster sessions their latest research results to the advanced manufacturing and broader engineering communities. Funds for the students' travel are based on the technical quality of the poster abstracts submitted as well as on a statement from the students' research advisors. Priority is given to student participants who are women or who come from underrepresented minority groups. This approach promotes diverse participation at the conference, in the short term, and in STEM fields, in the long term. This award benefits the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse manufacturing and engineering workforce better prepared to provide transformative solutions the challenges of their chosen fields.

This participation support is expected to benefit the students' professional, scientific and technical development. Attendance at the conference gives the students a broader view of the advanced manufacturing and engineering profession and of state-of-the-art research in their fields via access to several technical and professional development talks by leading domestic and international speakers. Students enhance their communication skills through oral and poster presentations, in-depth discussions of their work with peers in their fields during the Society-wide Poster Symposium at the Micro and Nanotechnology Forum. This interactive experience significantly broadens student education, increases their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaints them with expectations for scientific careers, and exposes them to new avenues for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the spirit of the mission of Directorate to attract young talented researchers and to mentor them for a career in science and engineering, this project provided NSF travel funding for students and postdocs to attend the 2019 ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE) in Salt Lake City, UT, (November 10-14, 2019) and present their research at the Society-Wide Micro and Nano Technology Forum. The conference provided a platform for networking between researchers from different institutions, which are expected to develop into potential opportunities for research collaboration. The focus areas for the conference being on topics of current national interests, the participants and audience were found to be in discussion about new research ideas during the poster session.

This project has greatly promoted the participation and will create a long impact for Society-Wide Micro and Nano Technology Forum. With support, we were able to attract 54 posters and provided travel support for 43 student presenters (as requested) including 9 minority students to showcase their scientific accomplishments, interact with their peers, and engage with people outside of their immediate academic environment at the Society-Wide Micro and Nano Technology Forum. This project provided an avenue for increased student exposure to cutting-edge research in the interdisciplinary areas of micro and nanotechnology, including advanced manufacturing, heat transfer, data science, as well as materials, mechanics, chemical, and bioengineering.

This NSF project facilitated the major goal of the conference, which is mentoring early stage next-generation workforce, primarily undergraduate and graduate students, although there was some participation from postdocs and faculty. This mix of researchers at different stages of their careers provided for a mentoring experience and presentation platform, especially for the first-time conference attendees and undergraduate students. It is anticipated that the motivation to pursue research in the discussed topics would lead to the development of the next generation of scientists and engineers focused on interdisciplinary scientific areas.

This award benefited the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse engineering workforce better prepared to provide transformative solutions to the challenges of their chosen fields. Attendance at the conference gave the students a broader view of the engineering profession and of state-of-the-art research in their fields via access to several technical and professional development talks by leading domestic and international speakers. Students enhanced their communication skills through poster presentations and in-depth discussions of their work with peers in their fields during the Society-Wide Micro and Nano Technology Forum. This interactive experience significantly broadened their education, increased their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquainted them with expectations for scientific careers, and exposed them to new avenues for innovative research.
